awd_titl_txt: Precision Measurement of 1S-2S Interval in Positronium
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve the accuracy of positronium (Ps) atom spectroscopy. Spectroscopy is important because the colors of light (or "spectrum") absorbed by atoms is a unique fingerprint that is useful for chemical identification in a broad range of applications found in medicine, defense, and industry. Spectroscopy can also reveal details about sub-atomic particles and their fundamental interactions.  Ps is a unique atom for this purpose.  Ps is formed by an electron bound with an anti-electron (positron).  Because Ps does not contain any protons or neutrons, spectroscopy of Ps atoms is an excellent test of bound-state quantum electrodynamics, a cornerstone theory for modern atomic physics.  This project will thus promote the progress of science.  This project will also help expand the nation's high technology work force by training students from diverse backgrounds to develop and implement high precision spectroscopy techniques.

The purely leptonic positronium (Ps) atom is uniquely well-suited for testing bound-state quantum electrodynamics (QED).  High accuracy Ps spectroscopy at the few parts per trillion level will provide background information that can be used to extract non-QED physics out of precision atomic measurements with heavier leptons and hadrons.  In this way, Ps spectroscopy can shed light on the proton charge radius puzzle.  It can also help constrain higher level recoil effect corrections in muonium. The previous precision measurement of the Ps 1S-2S interval, 1,233,607,216.4 +/- 3.2 MHz, performed by the coPI and S. Chu has stood for 25 years.  The uncertainty in this measurement came from positronium atoms spending too little time in the laser beam (transit time broadening), atoms moving too fast (second-order Doppler shift), laser intensity too high (AC Stark shift), and metrology limited at the ~1 MHz level.  This project will implement several new techniques to improve accuracy and precision. A position-sensitive time-of-flight detector will record the trajectory and speed of every detected atom as it passes through a larger laser beam profile, and thereby reduce the uncertainty due to second-order Doppler shifts, AC Stark Shifts, and transit-time broadening. A frequency-comb and a frequency-beat technique will be used to monitor the instantaneous laser frequency as positronium atoms transit the excitation beam.  These innovations should reduce the uncertainty in the measurement by a factor of 300, with the goal of reaching a 10 kHz uncertainty.  This work will train graduate students in a combination of atomic physics, positron science, laser spectroscopy, and metrology. This training will benefit the students as well as the Nation by providing highly skilled Ph.D.'s for the scientific workforce. UCR is a Department of Education Designated Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) with 30% of Physics majors and 15% of graduate students from under-represented ethnic minority groups. Several undergraduate researchers and a high school teacher will also be involved in these experiments, and this will help to attract more participants to STEM disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The interactions of the fundamental particles inside atoms underpins atomic physics, chemistry, and the structure of all matter. Our understanding of these interactions is based on precise measurements of the light that is emitted and absorbed by various atoms and molecules. The precise set of colors (or "resonant frequencies") of this light is a unique fingerprint that is used for chemical identification in a broad range of applications from medicine to defense and quality control in manufacturing. The precise measurement of the fingerprint can also tell us details about the fundamental particles that make up atoms.  Recently, a measurement of a particular resonant frequency in hydrogen (an electron bound to a proton) and muonic hydrogen (a heavy version of the electron, the muon, bound to a proton) caused a controversy in the atomic physics community about the nature of the proton and challenged whether the prevailing theory of atoms, bound-state quantum electrodynamics (QED for short) was incorrect. This controversy was eventually resolved by realizing that the fundamental Rydberg constant had a different value than had been previously agreed to on the basis of 20 previously published experimental values. By fitting 3 very precise measurements to fit a theory which assumes the QED theory is correct, and the Rydberg constant and the proton charge radius are free fit parameters, the researchers were able to convince the community and the international committee on fundamental constants to shift the Rydberg constant 7 standard deviations from the previous value. The goal of this project is to independently test bound-state QED theory by an experiment on the atom positronium. Positronium is a simple atom similar to hydrogen except it has one electron bound to one positron where the positron is the antimatter complementary particle to the electron. Unlike the proton in hydrogen, the positron is expected to be behave exactly according to QED and if the theory is correct, then the calculated value should match the experimental value perfectly without the non-QED correction terms required for hydrogen. As a result, the proposed measurement on positronium would be an actual test of the QED theory. This is important because QED theory is considered to be correct and underpins our understanding protons and nuclei (ie., nuclear physics), high energy physics and cosmology. Any disagreement with QED theory could have enormous impact not only in atomic physics but in many other areas of fundamental physics.

The current theoretical value is thought to have a precision of +-0.6 MHz and is 5.6 MHz higher than the previously measured value with an experimental uncertainty of +-3.2 MHz. During the period, improvements in the positron beam technology, laser systems, laser metrology, and positronium atom detection have improved the count-rate and expected uncertainty so a measurement at 1 MHz uncertainty should now be able to be performed in a matter of weeks of data taking instead of a year. While improvements are always beneficial for an experiment, they are vital for this challenging experiment so they can be completed in feasible laboratory conditions. 

The project has made a direct contribution to training four PhD graduate students.: 2 in Physics and 2 in Material Science and Engineering. Of these 4, one is an under-represented minority. The senior scientists involved with the project have a strong record in increasing diversity in physics. The PI has contributed to STEM education in grades 7-12 through interaction with the local Board of Education, outreach to students taking high school physics, and in participating in the UCR Summer Academy for High School Physics Teachers. The PI has incorporated this research project in various outreach talks as well as in undergraduate introductory college physics courses as an example of the scientific method in physics, i.e., experiments test the limits of our understanding in theories and if there are experimental disagreements, then the theories must be revised. It is an important reminder of the rigor of the science disciplines and a counter-example to recent challenges to science as "fake news". It is an example of why fundamental physics is important to the discipline and to society so it has confidence in the predictions of physics, which are the foundation for science and technology in modern society.
